desc: The MAPKAP1 gene encodes a protein (also known as SIN1) that is part of the mTORC2 complex, which is involved in cell growth and cytoskeletal organization (PMID: 19339977). MAPKAP1 acts not only as a scaffold protein for mTORC2 complex formation, but also as a key factor in mTORC2-mediated phosphorylation of AKT Ser473 (PMID: 24795562, 16962653, 17043309). In addition, MAPKAP1 is able to bind RAS and suppress its signaling (PMID: 17303383). MAPKAP1 is mutated or amplified at low frequencies in several cancers (cBioPortal, MSKCC, Nov 2016).

articles.title: Molecular mechanisms of mTOR-mediated translational control.
articles.reference: Ma XM et al. Nature reviews. Molecular cell biology. 2009 May;10(5)307-18.

articles.title: mTOR signaling and its roles in normal and abnormal brain development.
articles.reference: Takei N et al. Frontiers in molecular neuroscience. 2014;7()28.

articles.title: Human Sin1 contains Ras-binding and pleckstrin homology domains and suppresses Ras signalling.
articles.reference: Schroder WA et al. Cellular signalling. 2007 Jun;19(6)1279-89.

articles.title: Identification of Sin1 as an essential TORC2 component required for complex formation and kinase activity.
articles.reference: Yang Q et al. Genes & development. 2006 Oct 15;20(20)2820-32.

articles.title: SIN1/MIP1 maintains rictor-mTOR complex integrity and regulates Akt phosphorylation and substrate specificity.
articles.reference: Jacinto E et al. Cell. 2006 Oct 6;127(1)125-37.

desc: MAPKAP1, a component of the mTORC2 complex, is mutated or amplified at low frequencies in various cancers.
